title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement bonhomme.vincent@gmail.com. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Momstats • Statistics for morphometrics
text: goal ‘Momstats’ provide statistical methods top ‘Momocs2’ tibbles, chiefly multivariate methods morphometric data. includes mean shapes, principal component analyses along morphological space reconstruction, multivariate hypothesis testing, linear discriminant analyses permutations balancing, hierachical clustering methods, kmeans kmedoids, etc. Visualization heart several extensions ‘ggplot2’ graphics. light dispatching strategy makes comfortable consistent use.

what: Bottle outlines with elliptic Fourier transform coefficients — boteft
title: Bottle outlines with elliptic Fourier transform coefficients — boteft
text: dataset containing 40 bottle outlines preprocessed transformed using elliptic Fourier analysis. dataset used demonstrating statistical methods Momstats.

title: Bottle outlines with elliptic Fourier transform coefficients — boteft
code: boteft

title: Bottle outlines with elliptic Fourier transform coefficients — boteft
text: tibble 40 rows 5 variables: coo: List-column class c("", "coo", "list") containing outline coordinates (nx2 matrices). Outlines centered, scaled unit centroid size, aligned using PCA, rotated rightmost point 0 radians. coe: List-column class c("eft", "coe", "list") containing elliptic Fourier transform coefficients. element named numeric vector 24 coefficients (6 harmonics × 4 coefficients: , B, C, D) representing shape Fourier space. type: Factor 2 levels ("whisky", "beer") indicating bottle type. fake: Factor 1 level ("") - dummy grouping variable examples. price : Numeric random prices length: Numeric vector containing length outline along major inertia axis (computed standardization, also random ultimately depends size original images pixels...)

title: Bottle outlines with elliptic Fourier transform coefficients — boteft
text: Obtained :
code: bot %>%   mutate(length=unlist(get_length(coo))) %>%   coo_center() %>% coo_scale() %>% coo_align() %>%   coo_slide_direction("right") %>%   eft(6) %>% relocate(coe, .after=coo) -> boteft

title: Bottle outlines with elliptic Fourier transform coefficients — boteft
code: # View structure boteft #> # A tibble: 40 × 7 #>    id           coo       coe   type   fake  price length #>    <chr>        <out>     <eft> <fct>  <fct> <dbl>  <dbl> #>  1 brahma       (138 x 2) <24>  whisky a       3    1088. #>  2 caney        (168 x 2) <24>  whisky a       1.2   994. #>  3 chimay       (189 x 2) <24>  whisky a       3.8   644. #>  4 corona       (129 x 2) <24>  whisky a       2.6   806. #>  5 deusventrue  (152 x 2) <24>  whisky a       1.1   886. #>  6 duvel        (161 x 2) <24>  whisky a       3.1   606. #>  7 franziskaner (124 x 2) <24>  whisky a       2.6   865. #>  8 grimbergen   (126 x 2) <24>  whisky a       2.9   765. #>  9 guiness      (183 x 2) <24>  whisky a       1.2   742. #> 10 hoegardeen   (193 x 2) <24>  whisky a       3.6  1048. #> # ℹ 30 more rows  # Examine coefficient structure class(boteft$coe) #> [1] "eft"  "coe"  "list" class(boteft$coe[[1]]) #> [1] "eft"     "numeric" boteft$coe[[1]] #>            A1            A2            A3            A4            A5  #>  1.3427539129  0.0090863444  0.1248632443  0.0183772998  0.0314900219  #>            A6            B1            B2            B3            B4  #>  0.0113182436  0.0469665913  0.0003981801  0.0136025769  0.0019011705  #>            B5            B6            C1            C2            C3  #>  0.0057056253  0.0022844660  0.0134712409 -0.0021381830  0.0126151941  #>            C4            C5            C6            D1            D2  #> -0.0139137033  0.0110247077  0.0084896655 -0.3943943267  0.0618459428  #>            D3            D4            D5            D6  #> -0.0694671431  0.0465708687 -0.0526203987 -0.0140823150  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "eft"     "numeric"  # Unfold coefficients for statistical analysis boteft_unfolded <- unfold(boteft, coe)  # Or without prefix boteft_unfolded <- unfold(boteft, coe, .prefix = "")  # Principal component analysis on coefficients # pca_result <- stat_pca(boteft)  # Linear discriminant analysis by bottle type # lda_result <- stat_lda(boteft, type)

what: Collect predictions and LD scores from LDA results — collect.stat_lda
title: Collect predictions and LD scores from LDA results — collect.stat_lda
text: Extract predictions, posterior probabilities, optionally LD scores LDA result add tibble.

title: Collect predictions and LD scores from LDA results — collect.stat_lda
code: # S3 method for class 'stat_lda' collect(x, data = NULL, retain = FALSE, fold = FALSE, ...)

title: Collect predictions and LD scores from LDA results — collect.stat_lda
text: x stat_lda object data tibble. NULL, uses original data LDA. retain many LDs retain: FALSE (default): LD scores, predictions TRUE: LDs Integer (e.g., 2): First N LDs Numeric 0-1 (e.g., 0.95): LDs explaining proportion variance fold add LD scores (retain != FALSE): FALSE (default): Add separate columns (LD1, LD2, ...) TRUE: Fold single list-column named "lda" Character: Fold single list-column name ... Additional arguments (reserved)

title: Collect predictions and LD scores from LDA results — collect.stat_lda

title: Hierarchical clustering for morphometric data — stat_hclust

title: Hierarchical clustering for morphometric data — stat_hclust
text: "ward.D2" (default): Ward's minimum variance method - typically best morphometric data minimizes within-cluster variance "complete": Maximum distance clusters "average": UPGMA - average distance clusters "single": Minimum distance (tends chain)

title: Hierarchical clustering for morphometric data — stat_hclust

code: hc <- boteft %>% stat_hclust() boteft_clustered <- collect(hc, k = 4) # Cluster centers (if tree was cut) centers <- transduce(hc, tibble(cluster = 1:4))  # Any node in the tree node_shapes <- transduce(hc, tibble(node = c(45, 50, 55)))

title: Hierarchical clustering for morphometric data — stat_hclust
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Basic hierarchical clustering hc1 <- boteft %>% stat_hclust()  # With specific method hc2 <- boteft %>% stat_hclust(method = "average")  # Cut tree during creation hc3 <- boteft %>% stat_hclust(k = 4)  # Different distance hc4 <- boteft %>% stat_hclust(dist_method = "manhattan")  # Add cluster assignments boteft_clustered <- collect(hc1, k = 4)  # Get cluster center shapes centers <- transduce(hc3, tibble(cluster = 1:4))  # Get shapes at internal nodes nodes <- transduce(hc1, tibble(node = c(45, 50)))  # Plot (requires ape package) plot(hc1)  # Unrooted phylogram (default) plot(hc1, color = type)  # Color by grouping plot(hc1, type = "dendrogram")  # Classic dendrogram } # }

title: Linear Model for morphometric data — stat_lm
text: function automatically detects model direction formula: Shape regression (coe ~ predictors): Fits multivariate regression harmonics response Proper treatment shape correlated multivariate outcome Tests whether predictors affect shape Example: boteft %>% stat_lm(coe ~ length) Response regression (response ~ coe): Fits regression unfolded harmonics predictors Tests whether shape predicts response variable Example: boteft %>% stat_lm(length ~ coe) Multivariate response (cbind(y1, y2) ~ coe): Fits multivariate regression multiple responses Example: boteft %>% stat_lm(cbind(length, width) ~ coe)

code: lm_fit <- boteft %>% stat_lm(coe ~ length) boteft_pred <- collect(lm_fit)  # Adds fitted values new_shapes <- transduce(lm_fit, tibble::tibble(length = seq(50, 150, by = 10)))

Default TRUE. scale Logical NULL. data scaled unit variance? NULL (default), automatically determined based predictor types. ... Additional arguments passed stats::prcomp()

title: Principal Component Analysis for morphometric data — stat_pca
text: object class c("stat_pca", "momstats") containing: data: Original tibble (unchanged) model: stats::prcomp() object method: "pca" call: function call formula: Formula used () predictor_cols: predictor column names (coe + others) group_col: NULL (grouping PCA) variance_explained: Proportion variance explained PC cumvar_explained: Cumulative proportion variance explained center: Logical, centering applied scale: Logical, scaling applied

title: Principal Component Analysis for morphometric data — stat_pca
text: stat_pca() provides unified interface PCA morphometric coefficient data. handles: Automatic coefficient detection: Finds coe columns via class Coefficient unfolding: Expands list-columns individual harmonic columns Multiple coefficient types: Can combine different coefficient columns Covariates: Add non-morphometric predictors (size, environmental variables) Smart defaults: Automatically determines centering scaling

title: Principal Component Analysis for morphometric data — stat_pca
text: formula specifies predictors use: ~ coe: Use auto-detected coefficient column(s) ~ coe1 + coe2: Use specific coefficient columns ~ coe + size: Coefficient column plus covariate Bare name missing: auto-detect single coe column

title: Principal Component Analysis for morphometric data — stat_pca
text: center = TRUE (default): Variables centered mean = 0 scale = NULL (default): Automatic determination: Pure EFT coefficients: scale = FALSE Mixed predictors non-EFT: scale = TRUE scale = TRUE/FALSE: Override automatic behavior

title: Principal Component Analysis for morphometric data — stat_pca
text: Use collect() add PC scores data:
code: pca <- boteft %>% stat_pca() boteft_with_pcs <- collect(pca, retain = 5)  # Add first 5 PCs

title: Principal Component Analysis for morphometric data — stat_pca
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Basic PCA on coefficients pca1 <- boteft %>% stat_pca()  # Explicit column pca2 <- boteft %>% stat_pca(coe)  # Formula syntax pca3 <- boteft %>% stat_pca(~ coe)  # With covariate pca4 <- boteft %>% stat_pca(~ coe + length)  # Force scaling pca5 <- boteft %>% stat_pca(~ coe, scale = TRUE)  # Add PC scores to data boteft_pca <- collect(pca1, retain = 5)  # Or fold into single column boteft_pca <- collect(pca1, retain = 5, fold = "pca_scores")  # Plot results plot(pca1)  # Score plot (default) plot(pca1, type = "scree") plot(pca1, type = "loadings") plot(pca1, color = type)  # Color by grouping variable plot(pca1, labels = type)  # Text labels plot(pca1, color = type, chull = TRUE)  # With convex hulls } # }

title: Transduce model positions to coefficients and shapes — transduce.stat_lda
code: # S3 method for class 'stat_lda' transduce(object, positions)  # S3 method for class 'stat_pca' transduce(object, positions)  transduce(object, positions)

title: Transduce model positions to coefficients and shapes — transduce.stat_lda
text: object stat_* object (stat_pca, stat_lda, stat_lm, ...) positions tibble position coordinates. Column names must match model's coordinate system (e.g., PC1, PC2 PCA). row represents one position coefficients reconstructed.

title: Transduce model positions to coefficients and shapes — transduce.stat_lda
text: tibble columns: Position column(s): input positions tibble Coefficient column(s): coe (coe_A, coe_B, ...) proper classes Inverse shape column(s): coe_i (coe_A_i, coe_B_i, ...) matrices

title: Transduce model positions to coefficients and shapes — transduce.stat_lda
text: transduce() reconstructs coefficient vectors specified positions model space applies inverse transformations obtain shapes. positions tibble defines reconstruct shapes. PCA, columns named PC1, PC2, etc. Unspecified PCs default 0 (mean position). Shapes reconstructed using appropriate inverse method based coefficient class (eft_i, rft_i, opoly_i, etc.).

title: Transduce model positions to coefficients and shapes — transduce.stat_lda
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ pca <- boteft %>% stat_pca()  # Single axis pos <- tibble(PC1 = c(-2, 0, 2)) trans <- transduce(pca, pos)  # Two axes (manual grid) pos <- tibble(   PC1 = c(-2, 0, 2, -2, 0, 2),   PC2 = c(-1, -1, -1, 1, 1, 1) ) trans <- transduce(pca, pos)  # Or use expand_grid for convenience pos <- expand_grid(PC1 = c(-2, 0, 2), PC2 = c(-1, 1)) trans <- transduce(pca, pos)  # Access reconstructed shapes plot(trans$coe_i[[1]], type = "l") } # }

title: Transduce hierarchical clustering nodes to shapes — transduce.stat_hclust
text: hierarchical clustering, transduce can reconstruct shapes : Cluster centers (tree cut k h):   Returns mean shape cluster. node tree:   Returns mean shape descendants node. allows visualization "ancestral" shapes internal nodes. Node numbering follows stats::hclust() convention: Nodes 1 n: original observations (tips) Nodes n+1 2n-1: internal nodes merges
code: transduce(hc, tibble(cluster = 1:4)) transduce(hc, tibble(node = c(45, 50, 55)))

title: Transduce hierarchical clustering nodes to shapes — transduce.stat_hclust
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ hc <- boteft %>% stat_hclust(k = 4)  # Cluster centers centers <- transduce(hc, tibble(cluster = 1:4))  # Shapes at internal nodes hc2 <- boteft %>% stat_hclust() internal <- transduce(hc2, tibble(node = c(45, 50, 55, 60)))  # Root node (all data) root <- transduce(hc2, tibble(node = 2 * nrow(boteft) - 1)) } # }
